source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_011_chunk1
evidence_span: Well-controlled laboratory heat treatments were performed in the range from 460 to $6 1 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ (733 to $8 8 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ and from 1 to $\mathtt { 8 h }$ at temperature on Zircaloy-4 cladding tubes with three different degrees of initial cold work $( 4 0 \%$ , $6 4 \%$ , and $76 \%$ Within this range the influence of annealing temperature $T$ and time $t$ and of cold work on the yield strength $R _ { p 0 . 2 }$ at $4 0 0 ^ { \circ } C$ (673 K) and on the degree $R$ of recrystallization was experimentally determined.

evidence_span: It is nearly the same for all three materials. If you have a higher cold work you will have a finer grain size. The difference seems to be very small on tubing with various cold-work conditions.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_011_chunk5
evidence_span: We don't expect any differences. There usually are several process steps between the various heat treatments, usually including additional cold work.
process_step: alpha heat-treated, alpha plus beta heat-treated, beta heat-treated
